DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to see if different types of surgery for lung cancer have different effects on quality of life and pain. What we learn from this study may help us find new ways to improve the quality of life of lung cancer patients who have surgery.
DOC.brief_title: Quality of Life and Pain Outcomes Following Video-Assisted Thoracic Surgery (VATS) Anatomic Lung Resection Versus Thoracotomy and Anatomic Lung Resection
DOC.criteria: Patients with histologically confirmed or suspected clinical stage I non small cell lung cancer (including carcinoid tumors) based on standard staging (CT, PET, ± mediastinoscopy). Patients offered a VATS anatomic lung resection or a standard, posterolateral thoracotomy and anatomic lung resection at MSKCC. Patients cannot have had prior therapy, including surgery for the current lesion, systemic chemotherapy or external beam radiotherapy. KPS ≥ 70. Synchronous primaries within one lobe. Patients who have already undergone the planned operation. Patients who cannot tolerate segmentectomy or lobectomy. Patients with locally advanced or metastatic disease found either preoperatively or at the time of operation. Patients who are non English speaking Patients with multifocal disease Patients with concurrent cancers Patients with benign disease. Patients who are unwilling or unable to return to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center for postoperative followup for the first year following their operation.
